Dear CHRISTOPHER JOHNSON:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
November 20, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan
department of human services, the equivalent
state or Canadian provincial agency, or
2

equivalent agency in the country where the
person usually resides, that the person has
not been determined to be a perpetrator of
child abuse or child neglect. The
documentation shall be completed not more
than 30 days prior to the start of employment
and every 12 months thereafter.
One of fifteen new employee files did not have a central registry clearance
completed within 30 days prior to hire.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered any technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered any consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The first CAP was a result of the facility's 2023 Renewal Inspection due to
violations of Rules 113(1)(e) References, 113(1)(f)(ii) Criminal History clearances,
113(1)(i) Central Registry clearances, and 119(1) Social Services Worker. As a
result, the facility:
- Obtained new references for those who had references over 12 months
old.
- Updated the new hire personnel form to reflect employee file requirements
and position qualification requirements.
- Updated clearances for those who did not have clearances run on all
aliases/maiden names.
- Re-ran central registry clearances for those who did not have current
ones.
- Implemented a tracking system for central registry clearance completion
dates.
- Variance request was submitted for the case manager who did not meet
qualifications, and the request was approved by the DCWL director.
3

The second CAP was a result of SIR #2024SIC0001245 due to violations of Rule
127(4) and ACT 116 - 722.120(1)(c), As a result, the facility provided a staff to
resident ratio training, proactively created staffing schedules for six months,
completed a training regarding not falsifying documentation, provided a disciplinary
action to the staff involved in falsification of documents, updated the supervision
policy and daily shift log to reflect licensing rule requirements, and completed
biweekly video reviews to determine bed checks for youth were being done
properly and as staff documented.
Financial Overview
The facility's budget and financial audit were reviewed and there were no concerns.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not applicable.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) reported over all at the facility, things have been going
well. CA reported the corrective action plans implemented by the facility have been
successful. CA reported they have held trainings at biweekly and monthly meetings
with all staff to ensure understanding of policies and procedures. CA noted the
trainings they've held with staff have had a positive effect and have allowed staff to
feel open in asking questions or raising concerns about topics presented.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported the team is solid, and they have excellent teamwork. They reported
there's not a lot of staff turnover, so they have all been able to learn and work out
problems together as a team. They also feel it adds to more consistency in
programming and interactions with youth. Staff reported the Program Director and
Assistant Program Director, as well as the staffs' supervisors are always available
for questions and support. They reported management is open to feedback, and
they all work as a team to implement changes or solutions if identified. Staff
reported because there's not a lot of turnovers, staff tend to be more comfortable
addressing uncomfortable issues because there is more trust between them. Staff
reported any changes in policies, procedures, or safety measures are
communicated well. Staff reported there was approximately a 6-month gap where
they didn't have a consistent case management supervisor, so now that they have
one, it has made a very positive difference. Staff reported they feel trainings are
provided proactively, and if a suggestion is made about training needs, it is quickly
implemented. Staff reported if they need to be redirected, supervisors and upper
management do it in a proper and supportive way, rather than a punitive way.
4

Youth reported they feel safe at the facility, staff are great, and staff treat them well.
Youth reported they like the outings they're taken on as well as school. Youth
reported the food is good and they get enough to eat. No youth had any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walkthrough of the facility occurred on 11/20/24 and there were no concerns
noted. It should be noted there are only youth occupying Building 1 and Building 2.
Currently, the facility is not utilizing Building 3 for youth occupancy. However, one
hallway in Building 3 is set up for youth if needed. The other hallway in Building 3 is
currently being utilized for staff offices.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
